Award.AwardTitle: The Genetic Basis of Transgressive Variation in Rice
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Susan R. McCouch (Cornell University)

CoPI(s): Jason Mezey (Cornell University), Georgia C. Eizenga and Anna M. McClung (University of Arkansas/USDA-ARS Dale Bumpers National Rice Research Center)

Key Collaborator(s): Stefan Einarson (Cornell University) and Lewis H. Ziska (USDA-ARS Beltsville Agricultural Research Center)

This project will establish a joint forward-reverse genetics platform to facilitate the utilization of wild and exotic genetic materials in plant improvement and to accelerate the pace of discovery of genes and gene networks underlying transgressive variation in rice. Transgressive variation occurs in crosses between genetically divergent parents where offspring outperform the better parent. The nature of transgressive variation is that an individual locus' effect is dependent on other loci in the genetic background. Thus, the genetic dissection of transgressive variation necessitates modeling explicit gene interactions. Over the course of this project, models of genotype by genotype interaction(s) will be developed and validated, information that is key to manipulating non-additive genetic variation that can rapidly propel significant improvements in plant yield, adaptation and quality. In addition, this project will create a comprehensive genomics platform using wild and exotic rice germplasm to accelerate the pace of discovery of genes and gene networks underlying transgressive variation in rice for plant improvement. Specific objectives are to (1) re-sequence 30 diverse Oryza rufipogon accessions for the development of a 600K SNP chip for rice; (2) phenotype an expanded panel of wild and exotic rice germplasm for resistance to selected biotic and abiotic stresses; (3) create genetic materials for use in association mapping analyses and to rapidly translate discoveries into plant breeding applications; and, (4) develop integrated analysis techniques aimed at detecting non-additive genetic architecture associated with transgressive variation.

This project aims to gain a deeper understanding of the breadth and depth of genotypic and phenotypic variation within the rice gene pool and to empower the rice community to efficiently translate this knowledge into practical applications in plant improvement. Educational outreach activities will provide diverse opportunities for interdisciplinary, hands-on learning for high school, undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral fellows with emphasis on groups that are currently under-represented in science. The project will also continue and expand the 3-week Rice:Research to Production field-course in collaboration with the International Rice Research Institute (the Philippines). All of the data, germplasm and genomic resources developed on this project will be publicly available through project websites (www.ricediversity.org and www.ricesnp.org), the Gramene database (www.gramene.org), the International Rice Germplasm Center (IRGC), and the Genetic Stocks Center Oryza (GSOR) (www.gsor.gov).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The long-term goal of this project is to improve the rice-growing community’s ability to utilize natural variation to enhance the performance, quality and long-term sustainability of rice production systems. To do this, we have created an open-source rice diversity research platform that is enabling researchers to gain a deeper understanding of the breadth and depth of genotypic and phenotypic variation within the rice gene pool, and simultaneously empowering breeders to efficiently translate this knowledge into practical applications in plant improvement. This diversity would potentially lead to improved crop yields by allowing farmers to select seed varieties (e.g. drought-resistant, flood-tolerant, or disease-resistant) that would perform best in their local environment. As we deepen our understanding of the nature and extent of crop diversity, projects such as this enhance the potential to better utilize natural variation to breed new crop cultivars and develop new cropping systems with the performance characteristics required to meet the challenges of the future.

The project enabled fruitful collaborations with rice scientists around the world which supported five research objectives. First, the development of permanent collections of diverse wild and cultivated rice accessions (the “Rice Diversity Panels” or the RDPs) that are now publicly distributed as genetic stocks in the form of seeds. Second the genotyping of the RDPs using a custom-designed High Density Rice Array (700,000 SNPs) with open sharing of the genetic/genotypic data to enable other scientists to continue to develop useful analyses of plant performance. Third, the development and application of novel approaches to evaluating the RDPs for a wide array of complex, quantitatively inherited traits under both controlled and field conditions. Fourth, the development of a suite of analysis tools and visualization software to identify regions of the rice genome associated with both large and small phenotypic effects, which would facilitate future targeted breeding for specific characteristics. And lastly, the development of specialized plant populations to facilitate the identification of genes underlying complex traits and to expand the range of useful genetic diversity available for immediate use in applied plant breeding. The project also supported an active outreach program that included (A) an annual summer conference supporting a grass-roots initiative to support organic rice production in the Northeastern United States, (B) the development of interdisciplinary curriculum materials for use in middle and high schools in the US, (C) a 3-week field-course on Rice:Research to Production for young professionals at the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) in the Philippines, and (D) hosting a project web-site to ensure public availability of data, germplasm, genomic resources, publications, software, code and educational materials developed on this project.

Over the course of this project we have maintained productive interactions with scientists in all major rice producing regions of the world, and through our educational outreach activities we have provided diverse opportunities for interdisciplinary, hands-on learning for high school, undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral fellows with an emphasis on broadening participation of underrepresented groups in the US. Our activities have provided opportunities for young scientists and high school teachers to participate in both fundamental and applied science, and we have made significant contributions to the development of a new generation of leaders in international agriculture. The rice diversity research platform initiated as part of this project continues to expand and grow in keeping with its commitment to an open-access architecture.
